data.text: Muslim rule in the subcontinent
Prophet Muhammad <FONT SIZE="16" COLOR="">(PBUH)</FONT> was born in 570 <FONT SIZE="16" COLOR="">CE</FONT> in Makkah.
He received his first divine message from Allah in 610 and so declared the religion of Islam.
After Hazrat Muhammad <FONT SIZE="16" COLOR="">(PBUH)</FONT> passed away in 632, Islam spread from Arabia to other parts of Africa, Asia, and Europe.
In 712, Mohammad bin Qasim defeated Raja Dahir of Sindh and conquered the lands from the Arabian Sea coast up to Multan.
Mohammad bin Qasim established a strong and just government with good reforms for the people.
Due to these reforms, many people willingly converted to Islam.
By the end of the 11<FONT FACE="GG Superscript">th</FONT> century, Muslim rule was firmly established in the region that is now Pakistan.
The ruler of Ghazni, Mahmud, was among the early Muslim invaders from the north-west.
In 1192, the Afghan ruler, Mohammad Ghori conquered all of northern India up to Bengal.
Qutbuddin Aibak formed the Delhi Sultanate in 1206.
The Khaljis came to power and ruled from 1290 to 1320.
Ibn Batuta, the famous Arab traveller, lived at the court of Muhammad Tughlaq.
The Tughlaqs were followed by the Sayyids.
The Sayyids were followed by the Lodhis.
In 1398, Timur, the Mongol warlord, attacked and destroyed Delhi.
In 1526, Babur, the king of Kabul, defeated Ibrahim Lodhi and founded the Mughal Empire in the subcontinent.
Babur was succeeded by his son Humayun.
Humayun was defeated by the Afghan general Sher Shah Suri in 1540.
Humayun recovered his kingdom after the death of Sher Shah Suri.
Akbar was the greatest of all the Mughal kings who expanded the Mughal Empire. He ruled from 1556 to 1605.
Akbar was succeeded by Jahangir who ruled from 1605 to 1627.
Shah Jahan, the successor of Jahangir, built the world famous Taj Mahal in Agra.
Shah Jahan was succeeded by Aurangzeb who extended the Mughal Empire to its largest limit.
Due to Aurangzeb's constant war with the Marathas and the Rajputs, the Mughal Empire weakened.
The Mughal kings did much for the subcontinent.
